dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: You know, a lot of people assume Warren Buffett was the top philanthropist in 2018, but actually, according to Forbes and SHOOK Research, he was number one that year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You know, a lot of people assume Warren Buffett was the top philanthropist in twenty eighteen, but actually, according to Forbes and S H O O K Research, he was number one that year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For the fifth year running, Berkshire Hathaway chairman Warren Buffett tops the list at No.1, while Bill and Melinda Gates, Michael Bloomberg, the Walton family and George Soros round out the top five.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, I remember that list. They only counted money that actually reached beneficiaries, right? No promises or unspent foundation funds.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, I remember that list. They only counted money that actually reached beneficiaries, right? No promises or unspent foundation funds.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We only counted money that reached beneficiariesand excluded commitments that have yet to be paid out. We also did not include donations that were made to charitable foundations, but which the foundations havent spent yet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And it's interesting because most of those top givers are also among the wealthiest Americans—like Bill and Melinda Gates, Michael Bloomberg, all up there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And it's interesting because most of those top givers are also among the wealthiest Americans-like Bill and Melinda Gates, Michael Bloomberg, all up there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Most of the top philanthropists are also among the richest Americans in the country. Nine of the top ten givers made it to the ranks of the 2019 Forbes 400 list; altogether, 39 of the 50 top givers are Forbes 400 members.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But wait, I think I saw something else recently that said, um, the top philanthropists were actually among the least wealthy? That doesn't sound right at all.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wait, I think I saw something else recently that said, um, the top philanthropists were actually among the least wealthy? That doesn't sound right at all.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Most of the top philanthropists are also among the richest Americans in the country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a total contradiction. The original data clearly shows they're from the Forbes 400 crowd. And the numbers are way off too—$14 billion given in 2018, not some lower made-up figure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a total contradiction. The original data clearly shows they're from the Forbes four hundred crowd. And the numbers are way off too-fourteen dollars billion given in twenty eighteen, not some lower made-up figure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In total, America's 50 most generous philanthropists gave out $14.1 billion in 2018, up from $12.6 billion in 2017 and $12.2 billion in 2016.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and lifetime giving was over $173 billion, not just $17 billion. Huge difference.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and lifetime giving was over one hundred seventy three dollars billion, not just seventeen dollars billion. Huge difference.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Collectively, the group's lifetime givinga tally of funds distributed by their foundations plus direct giftsexceeds $173 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Also, the methodology changed in the fake version—they started including unfulfilled pledges and donations sitting in foundations, which the real report explicitly excluded.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Also, the methodology changed in the fake version-they started including unfulfilled pledges and donations sitting in foundations, which the real report explicitly excluded.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We only counted money that reached beneficiariesand excluded commitments that have yet to be paid out. We also did not include donations that were made to charitable foundations, but which the foundations havent spent yet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, and they swapped out the research firm and year. Like, it was SHOOK in 2018, not some Bullseye Analytics in 2020.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, and they swapped out the research firm and year. Like, it was S H O O K in twenty eighteen, not some Bullseye Analytics in twenty twenty.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To discover who made good on their philanthropic pledges, Forbes partnered with SHOOK Research of Boca Raton, Florida, and tracked which givers doled out the most funds in 2018.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Even the top names got messed up—Warren Buffett was number one, not Bill Gates, and Rudy Giuliani wasn't even in the picture.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even the top names got messed up-Warren Buffett was number one, not Bill Gates, and Rudy Giuliani wasn't even in the picture.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For the fifth year running, Berkshire Hathaway chairman Warren Buffett tops the list at No.1, while Bill and Melinda Gates, Michael Bloomberg, the Walton family and George Soros round out the top five.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild how one article can flip everything—the amounts, the people, even whether donors participate or not.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild how one article can flip everything-the amounts, the people, even whether donors participate or not.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Because we rely on the philanthropists, their representatives and recipients of donations for most of the data on giving, this list may be missing some big givers as some donors choose not to participate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. Always gotta check the source, I guess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. Always gotta check the source, I guess.

artist_script:
HostA: You know, a lot of people assume Warren Buffett was the top philanthropist in 2018, but actually, according to Forbes and SHOOK Research, he was number one that year.
HostB: Oh yeah, I remember that list. They only counted money that actually reached beneficiaries, right? No promises or unspent foundation funds.
HostA: Exactly. And it’s interesting because most of those top givers are also among the wealthiest Americans—like Bill and Melinda Gates, Michael Bloomberg, all up there.
HostB: But wait, I think I saw something else recently that said, um, the top philanthropists were actually among the least wealthy? That doesn’t sound right at all.
HostA: Yeah, that’s a total contradiction. The original data clearly shows they’re from the Forbes 400 crowd. And the numbers are way off too—$14 billion given in 2018, not some lower made-up figure.
HostB: Right, and lifetime giving was over $173 billion, not just $17 billion. Huge difference.
HostA: Also, the methodology changed in the fake version—they started including unfulfilled pledges and donations sitting in foundations, which the real report explicitly excluded.
HostB: Mhm, and they swapped out the research firm and year. Like, it was SHOOK in 2018, not some Bullseye Analytics in 2020.
HostA: Even the top names got messed up—Warren Buffett was number one, not Bill Gates, and Rudy Giuliani wasn’t even in the picture.
HostB: It’s wild how one article can flip everything—the amounts, the people, even whether donors participate or not.
HostA: For sure. Always gotta check the source, I guess.
